editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A comedy, as it was presented by her majesty's servants, at the private house in Drury lane.

Written by
George Chapman,
And James Shirley.
London, printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1639.

div.head: Actus primus.
div.stage: Enter sr. Marmaduke Travers, and Mr. Bostocke.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: Whether so fast sr. Marmaduke, a word.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My honourable blood? would I could stay
To give thee twenty, I am now engaged
To meet a noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Or rather
A gentlewoman, let her alone, and go
With me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I'll show thee a lady of fire.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A lady of the lake were not so dangerous.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I mean a spirit in few words, because
I love thee, I'll be open. I am going
To see my mistress.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I'll dispense with my
Occasion to see a handsome lady,
I know you'll choose a rare one.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She is a creature
Worth admiration, such a beauty, wit,
And an estate besides, thou canst not choose
But know her name, the lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Mine, whose but mine?
Am I not nobly born, does not my blood
Deserve her?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: To tell you truth, I was now going thither,
Though I pretended an excuse, and with
A compliment from one that is your rival.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I know not,
But she has half a score upon my knowledge
Are suitors for her favour.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Name but one,
And if he cannot show as many coats.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He thinks he has good cards for her, and likes
His game well.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Be an understanding knight,
And take my meaning, if he cannot show
As much in heraldry.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I do not know how rich he is in fields,
But he is a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Is he a branch of the nobility,
How many lords can he call cozen? else
He must be taught to know he has presumed
To stand in competition with me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You shall pardon me,
I have that within me must not be provoked,
There be some living now that ha' been killed
For lesser matters.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Some living that ha' been killed!

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I mean some living that ha' seen examples,
Not to confront nobility, and I
Am sensible of my honour.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: His name is
Sr. Ambrose.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Lamount a knight of yesterday,
And he shall die tomorrow, name another.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Not so fast sir. you must take some breath.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I care no more for killing half a dozen
Knights of the lower house, I mean that are not
descended from nobility, than I do
To kick any footman, and sr. Ambrose were
Knight of the sun, King Oberon should not save him,
Nor his Queen Mab.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Sr. Ambrose
How does thy knighthood? ha.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: My nymph of honour well, I joy to see thee.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Sr. Marmaduke tells me thou art suitor to
Lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I have ambition
To be her servant.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Hast, thar't a brave knight, and I commend
Thy judgement.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir Marmaduke himself leans that way too.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why didst conceal it, come, the more the merrier ▪
But I could never see you there.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I hope
Sir we may live.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I'll tell you gentlemen,
Cupid has given us all one livery,
I serve that lady too, you understand me,
But who shall carry her, the fates determine,
I could be knighted too.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That would be no addition to
Your blood.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I think it would not, so my lord told me,
Thou knowest my lord, not the Earl, my tother
Cousin, there's a spark his predecessors
Have matched into the blood, you understand
He put me upon this lady, I proclaim
No hopes, pray let's together gentlemen;
If she be wise, I say no more, she sha'not
Cost me a sigh, nor shall her love engage me
To draw a sword, I ha' vowed that.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Twere pity that one drop
of your heroic blood should fall toth' ground,
Who knows but all your cousin lords may die.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As I believe them not immortal sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Then you are gulf of honour swallow all,
May marry some Queen yourself, and get princes
To furnish the barren parts of Christendom.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Sir Marmaduke in private? my lady would
Speak with you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Tis her servant, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I hope he is not sent for.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: But come alone, I shall be troubled
With their inquiries, but I'll answer 'em.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: My lady would speak with you sir.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Not too loud, I was troubled with sr. Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I do not like this whispering,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Forget not the time, and to come alone.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My business is to you sir, these
Kept me off, my lady Lucina
Has a great mind to speak with you,
Little do these imagine how she honours me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: If I fail, may the surgeon
When he opens the next vein, let out all my honourable blood,
There's for thy pains, what thou shalt be hereafter
Time shall declare, but this must be concealed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: No, no I have no cause, you smile sr. Ambrose.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: But of our file, another of her suitors.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: My honoured knights, and men of lusty kindred.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Morrow to all gentlemen, I'll tell you
Who is returned?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: A friend of ours that went to travel.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: I saw him within these three minutes, and know not how I
Lost him again, he's not far off, d'ye keep a catalogue
Of your debts.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Such dulness in your memory, there was
About six months ago a gentleman
That was persuaded to sell all his land,
And to put the money out most wisely,
To have for one at his return from Venice,
The shotten herring, is hard by.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Jack Freshwater, I'll not see him yet.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: It will be for your honour, marry we
Without much stain, may happily compound,
And pay him nothing.
sp.stage: Enter freshwater, and monsieur le Friske.
sp.l: Here comes the thing
With what formality he treads, and talks,
And manageth a toothpick like a statesman.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I'll not bid him welcome home.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What's the tother rat that's with him?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: D'ye not know him, 'tis the court dancing weasel.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: A mere French footman sir, does he not look
Like a thing come off oth' saltcellar.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A dancer?
I would allow him gay about the legs,
But why his body should exceed decorum,
Is a sin oth' state.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: That's all.
I can inform you of their dance in Italy,
Marry that very morning I left Venice,
I had intelligence of a new device.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Si signior, I know not
What countryman invented, but they say
There be chopinoes made with such rare art,
That worn by a lady when she means to dance,
Shall with their very motion sound forth music,
And by a secret sympathy with their tread
Strike any tune that without other instrument,
Their feet both dance and play.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your lodging monsieur,
That when I have leisure I may dare
Present an humble servitor.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I do lie
At the sign of donna Margaretta de Pia
In the strand.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: At the maggot a pie in the strand sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: At de magpie boon adieu serviteur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: I'll speak to him,
Y' are welcome home sir.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: He wonot know me, this is excellent,
He shall be acquainted better, ere I part
With any sums.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Next time we'll not know him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Would all my creditors had this blessed ignorance.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Now colonel I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I shall meet you anon,
I am to wait upon a cousin of mine.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: My lord? Enter lord rainbow and Barker.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Your lordship honours me in this acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Y' are not a proclamation that every man is bound to take notice on,
And I cannot tell who you are by instinct.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Colonel? your humble servant, hark you Frank.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You are acquainted with my lord then,
Is he not a complete gentleman? his family
Came in with the conqueror.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: You had not else been kin to him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: A poor slip, a scion from that honourable tree.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: He is the lady's idol, they ha' not leisure
To say their prayers for him, a great advancer
Of the new ball.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Nay he's right, right as my leg colonel.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: But tother gentleman you do not know his inside.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I ha' seen him, he looks philosophical.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Who! he's the wit, whom your nobility
Are much obliged to for his company,
He has a railing genius, and they cherish it,
Fling dirt in every face when he's ith' humour,
And they must laugh, and thank him, he is dead else.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Or lose their mirth, he's known in every science,
And can abuse 'em all, some ha' supposed
He has a worm in's brain, which at some time
Oth' moon doth ravish him into perfect madness,
And then he prophesies, and will depose
The emperor, and set up Bethalem Gabre.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: He's dead, I hope he wonot conjure for him.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: His father sha'not scape him nor his ghost,
Nor heaven, nor hell, his jest must ha' free passage,
He's gone, and I lose time to talk on him,
Farewell,
Your countess
may expect too long,
Farewell colonel. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter lady Rosomond, and lady Honoria.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Why do you so commend him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Does he not
Deserve it? name a gentleman in the kingdom,
So affable, so moving in his language,
So pleasant, witty, indeed every thing
A lady can desire.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Sure thou dost love him,
I'll tell his lordship when I see him again,
How zealous you are in his commendation.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If I be not mistaken, I have heard
Your tongue reach higher in his praises madam,
Howe'er you now seem cold, but if you tell him
My opinion, as you shall do him no pleasure,
You can do me no injury, I know
His lordship has the constitution
Of other courtiers, they can endure
To be commended.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But I prithee tell me,
Is not love whence this proceeds, I have
I must confess discoursed of his good parts,
Desired his company.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You are not I hope jealous,
If I should say all night I need not blush,
It was but at a ball, but what of this?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I hope you ha' no patent
To dance alone with him, if he ha' privilege
To kiss another lady, she may say
He does salute her, and return a curtsy
To show her breeding, but I'll now be plainer,
Although you love this lord, it may possible
He may dispose his thoughts another way ▪

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Who can help it, he has eyes
To look on more than one, and understand
Perhaps to guide, and place his love upon
The most deserving object.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Most deserving,
This language is not levill with that friendship,
You have professed, this touches a comparison.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why do you think all excellence is thronged
Within your beauty.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You are angry lady,
How much does this concern you to be thus
Officious in his cause, if you be not
Engaged by more than ordinary affection.
I must interpret this no kind respect
To me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Good madam why? because,
I think, and tell you that another lady
May be as handsome in some man's opinion,
Admit I loved him too, may not I hold
Proportion with you, on some entreaty.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: They're loud, I'll not be seen yet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What is it that exalts you above all
Comparison? my father was as good
A gentleman, and my mother has as great
A spirit.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: 'Twill appear
No greater miracle in me I take it,
Yet difference will be, perhaps I may
Affect him with a better consequence.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Your consequence perhaps may be denied too,
Why there are no such wonders in your eye
Which other composition do not boast of,
My lord no doubt hath in his travels clapped
As modest cheeks, and kissed as melting lips.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: And yet mine are not pale.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: It may be they blush for the teeth behind them.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I have read
No sonnets on the sweetness of your breath.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: But I have heard of your tongue exalted much,
Highly commended.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not above your forehead,
When you have brushed away the hairy pentehrush,
And made it visible.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I'll now interrupt 'em.
They'll fall by the ears else presently.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Express it in discovery of that
Made you so earnest, I am confident
You were not practising a dialogue
To entertain me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Do not you blush, fie madam.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay and you come to blush once, and fie madam,
I'll know the secret, by this kiss I will,
And this.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You were kissed first, discover now
At your discretion.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My lord we were in jest.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It might ha' turned to earnest, if your lordship
Had not interposed.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: About a man ith' world, you are best name him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: You have the better gift at telling secrets.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Yet again, come I'll help it out, there is
A gentleman ith' world, some call a lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay nay, you must stand to't,
one, whom you
Love, it will appear no greater miracle
In you I take it, one no doubt that hath
Travelled, and clapped as modest cheeks, and kissed
As melting lips, thus far I'm right, but what
Name this most happy man doth answer too,
Is not within my circle.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Not to retain your lordship ith' dark,
Confident you'll not accuse my modesty
For giving you a truth, you shall not travel
Beyond yourself to find his name, but do not
Triumph my lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Am I so fortunate,
Then love I do forgive thee, and will cherish
The flame I did suspect would ruin me,
You two divide my love, only you two ▪
Be gentle in your empire heavenly ladies,
No enemy abroad can threaten you,
Be careful then, that you maintain at home
No civil wars.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: You are pleased to smile upon me gentle lady,
And I have taken it in my heart more than
Imaginary blessings with what pleasure
Could I behold this beauty, and consume
My understanding to know nothing else,
My memory to preserve no other figure.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My lord, I am not worth your flattery.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I flatter you? Venus herself be judge,
To whom you are so like in all that's fair,
'Twere sin but to be modest.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Do not mistake me, 'twere
A sin but to be modest in your praises,
Here's a hand, nature show me such another,
A brow, a cheek, a lip, and every thing,
Happy am I that Cupid's blind.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If he could see, he would forsake his mistress
To be my rival, and for thy embraces
Be banished heaven.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: My lord I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If you did know how great a part of me,
Will wither in your absence, you would have
More charity, one accent of unkind
Language from you, doth wound me more than all
The malice of my destinies, o dear madam,
You say you'll take your leave of your poor servant ▪
Say rather, you will dwell for ever here,
And let me stay and gaze upon
Your heavenly form.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I can be patient
To hear your lordship mock me, these are but
A course reward for my good thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: This 'tis to use plain dealing, and betray the inside
Of our hearts to women, did you think well of me
So late, and am I forfeited already,
Am I a christian?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Make me not miserable then, dear madam,
With your suspicion, I dissemble with you,
But you know too well what command your beauty
Has upon me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Give me leave
My lord to wonder you can love me,
With such a flame you have expressed yet she,
Your mistress?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I like not this so well.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: There is no way but one to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I wish my lord I had the art to effect
What you desire.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: It is within
Your powers.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Since it is so
That I'm not able to determine which
My heart, so equal unto both, would choose,
My suit is to your virtues, to agree
Between yourselves, whose creature I shall be ▪
You can judge better of your worths than I,
My allegiance shall be ready if you can
Conclude which shall ha' the supremacy;
Take pity on your servant gentle ladies,
And reconcile a heart too much divided,
So with the promise of my obedience
To her that shall be fairest, wisest, sweetest
Of you two, when I next present a lover,
I take distracted leave. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Why, this is worse than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: He's gone,
And has referred himself to us.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: This will
Ask counsel.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And some time I would be loath
To yield.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: And I, Cupid instruct us both. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And what made you to undertake this voyage ▪
Sweet signior freshwater.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: An affection
I had to be acquainted with some countries.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And you return fraught home with the rich devices ▪
Fashions of steeples, and the situations
Of galouses, and wit no doubt a bushel,
What price are oats in Venice?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Signior
I kept no horses there, my man, and I

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Give him good words, a pox take him.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Which I reduced into a narrow compass,
Some call it selling.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: He would sell bargains of a child.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: It was but two hundred pound per annum sir,
A loan revenue.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And did you sell it all?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I did not leave an acre, rod, or perch,
That had been no discretion, when I was selling
I would sell to purpose, do you see this roll,
I have good security for my money sir,
Not an egg here but has five chickens in't,
I did most politicly disburse my sums,
To have five for one at my return from Venice,
And now I thank my stars I am at home.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And so by consequence in three months your estate
Will be five times as much or quintupled.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes signior quintupled,
I wonot purchase yet I mean to use
This trick seven years together, first
I'll still put out, and quintuplie as you call't,
And when I can in my exchequer tell
Two, or three millions, I will fall a purchasing.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I have a mind to buy
Constantinople from the Turk, and give it
The emperor.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What think you of Jerusalem?
If you would purchase that, and bring it nearer,
the Christian pilgrims would be much obliged to ye,
When did you wash your socks?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Then 'tis your breath, to your lodging ▪ and perfume it,
You'll tell the sweeter lies to them that will
Lose so much time to ask about your travel,
You wonot sell your debts?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Have you as much left in ready cash as will
Keep you and this old troll a fortnight longer,
Die, and forgive the world, thou mayst be buried,
And ha' the church-cloth, if you can put in
Security, the parish shall be put
To no more charge, dost thou hope to have a penny
Of thy own money back, is this an age
Of five for one, die ere the town takes notice,
There is a hideous woman carries ballets,
And has a singing in her head, take heed
And hang thyself, thou mayst not hear the time,
You remember Coriate.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: We'll ha' more verses o'thy travels coxcomb,
Books shall be sold in bushels in cheap side,
And come in like the peascods, wain loads full
Of thee, and thy man apple John that looks
As he had been a seven-night in the straw
A ripening for the market, farewell rusiting,
Thou art not worth my spleen, do not forget
My counsel, hang thyself, and thou goest off
Without a session's. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Fine, I'm glad he's gone, Gudgine, what dost thou think.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: I think you're well rid of railing madcap.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay, nay he'll not spare a lord
But were not I best call in my money's gudgeon,
My estate wonot hold out, I must be more
Familiar with my gentlemen. Enter lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Was it not Frank Barker that parted from you?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: There is a sum, my lord.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: There was a sum my lord delivered
From your poor servant freshwater.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I remember,
But I have business now, come, home to me,
The money's safe, you were to give me five ▪
For one at your return.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I five? Your lordship has forgotten the cinquepace.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Something it is, but when I am at leisure
We will discourse of that, and of your travel,
Farewell signior. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Is't come to this? if lords play fast and loose,
What shall poor knights, and gentlemen?
Hum, 'tis he. Enter colonel.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: A pox upon him, what makes he in my way.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: A wy, je ne pa parlee anglois,
There were five English pieces.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Je ne parle anglois, me speak no word English,
Votre seviteur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Adieu five pieces,
Gudgeon gape, is't not he?
They wonot use me o'this fashion,
Did he not speak to me ith' morning?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I think so,
But then you would not know him in Italian,
And now he will not know you in French.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Call you this selling of land, and putting out money
To multiply estate?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: To quintuply five for one, large interest.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Five for one, 'tis ten to one if I get my principal.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Your roll is not at the bottom, yet try the rest.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I met him opportunely after all the rest,
And told him how much it would concern
His livelihood to make haste.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: He must not be seen yet, you know where
To attend for him, give him access by
The garden to my chamber, and bring
Me nimbly knowledge when he is there.

div.stage: Enter the dancer, lady Rosomond, lady Lucina, and lady Honoria.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Very well an dat be scurvy you run trot, trot, trot,
Pisha, follow me, fout madame, can you not tell
So often learning — madam you foot it now
Plam it ill. Another lady dances.
Excellent, better den excellent pishaw — you be laughed
When you come to do ball; I teach tree hundred, never
Forgotten so much, me sweat taking pain, and fiddling ladies.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Purquoy for telling you
Dance not well, you commit fat, and beat me for my
Diligence becar you dance your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No monsieur le Friske put not up your pipe, my lady
Was but in jest, and you must take it for a favour.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: I veare no favours in dat place, should any gentleman
Of England give me blow, diable me teach him French passage.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nay you sha'not be so angry, I must have a coronte,
Pray madam be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Sorre, tat is too much par ma foy, I kiss tat white hand,
Give me one two tree buffets, aller, aller look up your
Countenance, your English man spoil you, he no teach
You look up, pishaw, carry your body in the swimming
fashion, and deum allei moy moselle ha, ha, ha,
So for boon excellent becar. Dance.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay a country dance Scutilla, you are idle,
You know we must be at the ball anon, come.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.p: Where is the ball this night.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: O he dance finely becar, he deserve the ball of de world,
Fine, fine gentleman, your oder men dance lop, lop with
De lame leg as they want crushes begore, and look for
Argent in the ground pishaw,
sp.stage: They dance a new country dance.
sp.l: Ha, hah, for boon.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Now madam we take our leave.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll recompense this kind visit: does your coach stay?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Yes madam,
Your ladyship will be too much troubled.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.p: I have more lady, my scholars.

sp.speaker: Sciu.
sp.p: Is that the way of your instrument.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: All a murdu France, fit, fit adieu
Madam votre serviteur,
Adieu demi monsieur. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: The time's too narrow to discourse at large,
But I intend you a service,
You have deserved it
In your own nobleness to one I call a kinsman,
Whose life without your charity had been
Forfeit to his general's anger, 'twas not
Without his cause you after quit your regiment.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: He was my friend, forget it.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: You were sent for
By the lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: 'Twas my desire to prepare you for
the entertainment, be but pleased to obscure
Yourself behind these hangings a few minutes,
I hear her, you may trust me.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: Without dispute, I obey you lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Now Scutilla we are ripe, and ready
To entertain my gamesters, my man said
They promised all to come, I was afraid
These ladies in their kind departure would not
Bequeath me opportunity, and the mirth
Doth in the imagination so tickle me,
I would not willingly ha' lost it for a jewel
Of some value.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If they hold their affections, and keep touch,
We'll ha' some sport. Enter Solomon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Away Scutilla, and
Laugh not loud between our acts, we'll meet
Again like music, and make ourselves merry.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sr. Markmaduke I thought I should have had
Your visit without a summons.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Lady you gave
One feather to the wings I had before,
Can there be at last a service to employ
Your creature?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Something hath pleaded for you in your absence.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O let me dwell upon your hand, my stars
Have then remembered me again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How do the fens?
Goes the draining forward, and your iron Mills?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Draining, and iron mills? I know not madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come, you conceal your industry, and care
To thrive, you need not be so close to me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: By this hand lady, have I any iron mills?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am abused else, nay I do love
one that has windmills in his head.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Projects, and proclamations, did not you
Travel to Yarmouth to learn how to cast
Brass buttons, nay I like it, it is an age
For men to look about 'em, shall I trust
My estate to one that has no thrift, a fellow
But with one face? my husband shall be a Janus,
He cannot look too many ways, and is
Your patent for making vinegar confirmed:
What a face you put upon't nay, ne'er dissemble,
Come I know all, you'll thank that friend of yours,
That satisfied my inquiry of your worth
With such a welcome character, but why
Do I betray myself so fast? beshrew
His commendations.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How is this? somebody
That meant me well, and knew her appetite
To wealth hath told this of me, I'll make use on't;
Well madam, I desired these things more private
Till something worth a mine, which I am now
Promoving had been perfect to salute you,
But I perceive you hold intelligence
In my affairs, which I interpret love,
And I'll requite it, will you be content
Be a countess for the present.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I shall want
No honour in your love.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A licence, and say no more,
How blessed am I, do not blush,
I wonot kiss your lip, till I ha' brought it.Exit

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Yes madam you have kept your word,
The knights transported, gone
to prepare things for the wedding.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How didst thou like the iron mills.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: And the brass buttons rarely, have you devices
To jeer the rest.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All the regiment on 'em, or I'll break my bowstrings.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Away, and let the swallow enter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why sirrah, did I command you give access to none ▪
But sr. Ambrose Lamount?
Whom you know I sent for,
Audacious groom.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is sr. Ambrose coxcomb, is it not,
Cry mercy noble sir, I took you muffled
For one that every day solicits me
To bestow my little dog upon him, but you're welcome,
I think I sent for you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: It is my happiness
To wait your service lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I hear say you have vowed to die a bachelor,
I hope it is not true sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that you'll turn religious knight.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I turn religious knight, who has abused me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would only know the truth, it were great pity,
For my own part I ever wished you well,
Although in modesty I have been silent,
Pray what's o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I had a dream last night, methought I saw you
Dance so exceedingly rarely, that I fell
In love.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: My leg is at your service to come over.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I wondered at myself, but I considered,
That many have been caught with handsome faces,
so my love grew.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What followed in my dream
I ha' forgotten.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Since the morning
I find some alteration, you know
I have told you twenty times I would not love you,
But whether 'twere your wisdom or your fate
You would not be satisfied, now I know not
If something were procured, what I should answer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Would were my estate were doubled.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You have not purchased since you fell in love?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Revels have been some charge to you, you were ever
A friend to ladies, pity but he should rise
By one, has fallen with so many, had you not
A head once?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: A head? I have one still.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Of hair I mean,
Favours ha' gleaned too much, pray pardon me
If it were mine, they should go look their bracelets,
Or stay till the next crop, but I blush sir
To hold you in this discourse, you will perhaps
Construe me in a wrong sense; but you may use
Your own discretion till you know me better,
Which is my soul's ambitions.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Cunning Gipsy she'll use me thus too
When I come to't?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Lady I know your mind, when I see you next. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You'll see me again, ha ha ha, Scutilla.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Here madam almost dead with stifling my laughter,
Why he's gone for a licence, you did enjoin him no silence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would have 'em all meet and brag o'their several
hopes they wonot else be sensible, and quit me o'their
Tedious visitation, who's next?
I would the colonel were come,
I long to have about with him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Retire, and give the lay admittance.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Madam, I kiss your fair hand.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Two not become your birth, and blood to stoop
To such a title.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I must confess dear lady,
I carry in my veins more precious honour
Then other men, blood of a deeper crimson,
But you shall call me any thing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not I sir,
It would not become me to change your title,
Although I must confess I could desire
You were less honourable.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why I prithee,
Is't a fault to spring from the nobility?
There be some men have sold well favoured lordships,
To be ill favoured noblemen, and though
I wear no title of the state, I can
Adorn a lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That is my misfortune,
I would you could not sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Are you the worse
For that? consider lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have considered,
And I could wish with all my heart you were
Not half so noble, nay indeed no gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, if you give me leave to speak my thoughts,
I would you were a fellow of two degrees
Beneath a foot man, one that had no kindred,
But knights oth' post, nay worse, pardon me sir,
in the humour I am in, I wish, and heartily,
You were a son oth' people rather then.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Good madam give me your reason.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Few women wish so ill to whom they love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: They do not love like me then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My wealths a beggar, nay the title of
A lady which my husband left, is a shadow
Compared to what you bring to ennoble me,
And all the children you will get, but I
Out of my love desire you such a one,
That I might add to you, that you might be
Created by my wealth, made great by me,
Then should my love appear, but as you are,
I must receive addition from you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nobody hears, why hark you lady, could
You love me, if I were less honourable?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Honourable? why you cannot be so base
As I would have you, that the world might say
My marriage gave you somewhat.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Say you so,
Under the rose, if that will do you a pleasure,
The lords do call me cousin, but I am.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Not to be lawful, I came in at the wicket,
Some call it the window.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I prefer you before all my suitors,
Sr. Ambrose Lamount, and sr. Marmaduke
Travers are all mountebanks.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A lanse pre sado, how my joy transports me,
But shall I trust to this, do not you flatter?
Will not you fly from that, and be legitimate,
when we are married, you men are too cunning
With simple ladies.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do but marry me,
I'll bring the midwife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Say no more, provide
What you think necessary, and all shall be
Dispatched.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I guess your meaning, and thus seal
My best devotion. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Scutilla, hold me, I shall fall
In pieces else, ha ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Beshrew me madam, but I wonder
At you, you wound him rarely up.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Have not I choice of precious husbands? now and
The colonel were here, the task
Were over.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Then you might go play,
Madam the colonel.

sp.speaker: Lue.
sp.p: Is he come once more? withdraw, bid him march hither.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Now is my turn madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You're welcome sir, I thought you would have gone,
And not graced me so much as with a poor
Salute at parting.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: She jeers me already, no lady I'm already
Engaged to a siege at home, and till that service
Be over, I inquire no new employments.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: A citadel,
That several forces are set down before,
And all is entrenched.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Ostend was sooner taken then her fort
is like to be for any thing I perceive.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Her provision
May fail her, but she is devilish obstinate,
She fears nor fire nor famine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, alas poor colonel;
If you'll take my advice remove your siege,
A province will be sooner won in the
Low countries, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Twas but to tell you my opinion in this business,
You'll sooner circumcise the Turks dominions,
Then take this toy you talk off, I do know it,
Farewell good soldier, ha ha ha, and yet 'tis pity,
Is there no stratagem, no trick, no undermine;
If she be given so desperate, your body
Had need to be well victualled, there's a city
And suburbs in your belly, and you must
Lay in betimes to prevent mutiny
Among the small guts, which with wind of venge else
Will break your guard of buttons, ha ha ha
Come we'll laugh, and lie down in the next room Scutilla.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: So so, I did expect no good,
Why did not I strike her, but I'll do something,
And be with you to bring before you think out,
Malice and Mercury assist me. Exit.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: So so, you've a precious time on't.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who can help it Frank, if ladies will
Be wild, repentance tame 'em, for my part
I court not them, till they provoke me to't.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And do they both affect you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So they say,
And did justify it to my face.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And you did praise their modesty.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I confess I praised 'em
Both when I saw no remedy.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Do not
Do not believe it my young lord, they'll make
Fools of a thousand such, they do not love you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Why, and shall please your wisdom?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: They are women,
That's a reason, and may satisfy you,
They cannot love a man.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Themselves,
And all little enough, they have a trick
To conjure with their eyes, and perhaps raise
A masculine spirit, but lay none.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Good Cato
Be not overwise now, what's the reason
That women are not sainted in your calendar,
You have no frosty constitution?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Would you were half so honest.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why a woman
May love thee one day.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yes when I make legs
And faces like such fellows as you are.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Monsieur la Friske. Enter monsieur la Friske ▪

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Nay Frank thou shalt not go.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I'll come again when you ha' done your jig.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Come you shall sit down, this fellow will make thee laugh.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I shall laugh at you both, and I stay.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Hark you monsieur, this gentleman has a great
mind to learn to dance.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: He command my service,
Please your lordship begin that he may
See your profit alkey — hah.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Well enough for the dog-days, but have
You no other dancing for the winter, a man
May freeze and walk thus.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: It be all your grace monsieur, your
Dance be horseplay begar for de stable not
De chamber, your ground passage hah
Never hurt de back monsieur, nor trouble
De leg much, hah plait ill you learn
Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: For mirth' sake, and thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Begar I teach you presently, dance with all de
Grace of de body for your good, and my profit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I shall never endure it, pox upon him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: 'Tis but dis in de beginning, one, two, tree, four, five, the
Cinquepace, alley monsieur, stand upright an begar.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Let him set you in tooth posture.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: My brother my lord know well for de little kit he fiddle
And me for de posture of de body, begar de King has no too
Sush subjects hah, dear be one foot, two foot, have
You tree foot, begar you have more den I have den.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: One, been two hah, you go to fast, you be at Dover
Begar, and me be at Greenwich, tree toder leg pishaw.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: A pox upon your legs, I'll no more.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, I would some ladies were here to laugh
At thee now, you wonot ▪ be so rude to meddle with
The monsieur in my lodging.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I'll kick him to death, and bury him in a bass-viol jackalent.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Jackalent, begar you be jackanapes, if I had my weapon
You durst no affront me, I be as good gentleman, an for
All my fiddle as you, call me a jack a de lent.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Rail upon him monsieur, I'll secure thee, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Because your leg have de poc, or something dat make
'Em no vell, and frisk, you make a fool of a monsieur.
My lord use me like gentleman, an I care no rush for
You, be desperate, kill me, and me complain to de
King, and teach new dance, galliard to de gibbet, you
Be hanged in English fashion. Exit

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Go, you're an impertinent lord, and I will be revenged

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, good Diogenes, come monsieur,
You and I wonot part yet.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: My lord, if you had not been here, me would have
Broken his head with my fiddle.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You might sooner have broke your fiddle, but strike up.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Allei hah boon. They dance in.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I spy sir Marmaduke coming after me,
This way I'll take to avoid his tedious questions,
He'll interrupt me, and I ha' not finished
Things fit for my design.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Tis Mr. Bostocke, little does he think
What I am going upon, I fear I sha'not
Contain my joys.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sir you must pardon, I cannot wait
Upon you now, I ha' business of much consequence.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I thought to have made the same excuse to you,
For at this present I am so engaged.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Poor gentleman how is he beguiled.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Your nose is wiped, hum, 'tis sr. Marmaduke,
I must salute him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: The colonel? there's no going back.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What misfortune's this? but 'tis no matter,
Noble sir how is't?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: As I could wish noble Mr. Bostocke,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I sha'not forbear jeering these poor things,
They shall be mirth.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: What all met so happily? and how my
Sparks of honour?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Things so tickle me,
I shall break out.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: When saw, you our mistress lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: My suit is cold there, Mr. Bostocke carries
The lady clean before him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No no not, it is sr. Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I glean by smiles after sr. Ambrose.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: None of you see her today?
I may as soon marry the moon, and get
Children on her, I see her not this three days,
'Tis very strange, I was to present my service
This morning.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: I cannot tell, but there's small sign of victory,
And yet methinks you should not be neglected,
If the fens go forward, and your iron mills.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Some are industrious,
And have the excellent skill to cast brass buttons.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: How will you sell your vinegar a pint,
The patent something saucy.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Had not you a head once,
Of hair I mean, favours ha' gleaned too much,
If ladies will ha' bracelets, let 'em stay
Till the next crop.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Hum, the very language she used to me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Does he jeer him too, nay nay, prithee spare him. ha ▪ ha.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: You may do much, and yet I could desire
You were less honourable, for though you have
Blood of a deeper crimson, the good lady
Out of her love could wish you were a thing
Beneath a foot man, and that you had no kindred
But knights oth' post.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Nay pardon me,
In the humour I am in, I wish, and heartily,
You were a son oth' people.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Colonel,
How the devil came he by this?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Under the rose there was a gentleman
Came in at the wicker, these are tales of which
The Greeks have store, fair hopes gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How came you by this intelligence.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Nay I'll no whispering, what I say to one
Will concern every man, she has made
You coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: And more than does appears yet
I had my share.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: That's some comfort, I was afraid.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: But you shall pardon me, I'll conceal
The particulars of her bountiful abuses
To me, let it suffice I know we are all
Jeered most abominably, I stood behind
The hangings when she signed your several passes,
And had my own at last worse than the constables,
That this is true, you shall have more than oath,
I'll join we in revenge, and if you wonot,
I will do't alone.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Damn her then, till we think on something else,
Let's all go back, and rail upon her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: We cannot be too bitter, she's a hell cat.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: D'ye hear, listen to me our shames are equal,
Yet if we all discharge at once upon her,
We shall but make confusion, and perhaps
Give her more cause to laugh, let us choose one,
To curse her for us all.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: 'Tis the best way, and if you love me gentlemen,
Engage me, I deserve this favour for my
Discovery, I'll swear her into hell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Troth I ha' no good vein, I me content.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Gentlemen, noble colonel as you respect
A wounded branch of the nobility,
Make it my office, she abused me most, and if
The devil do not furnish me with language,
I'll say he has no malice.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: But let's us all together, I'll not be barred,
Now and then to interpose an oath,
As I shall find occasion.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You'll relieve me
When I take breath, than you may help, or you,
Or any to confound her.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Noble Mr. freshwater welcome from travel.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: In the next room sir;
My lady Rosamond is sitting for her picture,
I presume you will be welcome.

div.stage: He gives freshwater access to the chamber and returns.

sp.speaker: Sol,
sp.l: This way,
Honest gudgeon,
How, and the matters abroad, a touch of
thy travel, what news.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: First, let me understand the state of things
At home.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: We have little alteration since thou wentest,
The same news are in fashion,
Only gentlemen are fain to ramble, and stumble
For their flesh since the breach oth' bank side.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Yet the viragoes ha' not lost their spirit, some on
'Em have challenged the field, every day where
Gentlemen have met 'em, o the dog-days bit
Shrewdly, 'twas a villainous dead vacation.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Yes, yes, a little sick oth' stone, she voids some
Every day, but she is now in physic,
And may in time recover.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Longer than a church,
There is no fear while the merchants have faith;
A little of thy travels, for the time is precious, what
Things have you seen or done since you left England?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: I have not leisure to discourse of particulars, but first
My Mr. and I have run France through, and through.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Through and through, how is that man?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: Why once forward, and once backward, that's through
And through.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: 'Twas but a cowardly part to run a kingdom
Through backward.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Not with our horses Solomon, not with our horses.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Madam, I did not think your ladyship
Had so little judgement

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: As to let an English man draw
Your picture, and such rare mounsieurs in town.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: O by no means madam,
They ha' not active pencils.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You must encourage strangers while you live,
It is the character of our nation,
We are famous for dejecting our own countrymen.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why so, 'tis necessary,
Trust while you live the Frenchman with your legs,
Your faces with the Dutch, if you mislike
Your faces, I mean if it be not sufficiently
Painted, let me commend upon my credit
A precious workman to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Not an English man I warrant you,
One that can please the ladies every way,
You sha'not sit with him all day for shadows,
He has regallias, and can present you with
Suckets of fourteen pence a pound, canary,
Prunellas, Venice glasses, parmesan,
Sugars, Bologuia, sausages all from Antwerp;
But he will make ollepodredos most incomparably.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I have heard of him by a noble lady
Told me the tother day, that sitting for
Her picture, she was stifled with a strange
Perfume of horns.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: A butcher told me of 'em, very likely.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: When I have need
Of this rare artist I will trouble you
For my directions, leaving this discourse,
How thrives your catalogue of debtors signior.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You sha'not name me in the list of any
That are behind, beside my debt a purse
For clearing the account.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You are just madam,
And bountiful, though I came hither with
Simple intention to present my service
it shall be crossed. Gudgeon remember too,
Her ladyship's name.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My cousin has the
Same provision for you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Madam I'll take my leave, I'll find another
Time to attend my lady, there's no light,
I cannot abide this fellow. Exit with Gud.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Madam, master Barker hath some design
Which he pretends concerns us both.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: My lord commends him to ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The lord, the fine, the wanton dancing lord,
The lord that plays upon the gittern, and sings,
Leaps upon tables, and does pretty things,
Would have himself commended.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He loves you both, he told me so,
And laughs behind a vizard at your frailty,
He cannot love that way you imagine,
And ladies of the game are now no miracles.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Although he use to rail thus, yet we have
Some argument to suspect his lordship's tongue
Has been too liberal.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I find it too, and blush within to think
How much we are deceived, I may be even
With this may-lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: But does his lordship think
We were so taken with his person.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You would not, and you knew as much as I.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I ha' been acquainted with his body
Ha known his baths and physic.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Is't possible, I am sorry now at heart.
I had a good thought on him, he shall see't,
For I will love some other in revenge,
and presently if any gentleman
Ha but the grace to smile, and court me up to't.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: A bubble of nobility, a giddy
Fantastic lord, I want none of his titles,
Now in my imaginations he appears
Ill favoured, and not any part about him
Worth half a commendation, would he were here.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That I might examine,
And do my judgement right between you two now ▪
How much he would come short, you have an eye
Worth forty of his, nose of another making;
I saw your teeth e'en now compared to which,
His are of the complexion of his comb,
I mean his box, and will in time be yellower,
And ask more making clean, you have a show
Of something on your upper lip, a witch
Has a philosopher's beard to him, his chin
Has just as many hounds as hairs that ever
My eyes distinguished yet, you have a body
And unpromising in his slashes, one
May see through him, and for his legs they both
Would but make stuffing for one handsome stocking,
They're a lord's I will be sworn, I dote upon him,
I could wish somewhat, but I me sworry sir
To trouble you so much, all happy thoughts
Possess you.Exit

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: How is this, if I have wit
To apprehend, this lady does not hate me?
I have professed a cynic openly,
This language melts, I'll visit her again.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Sir, I have a small request to you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you think I have power
Or will to deserve from you any courtesy,
Pray learn to dance.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: At my entreaty sir to dance,
It was the first thing took me with his lordship,
You know not what may follow, fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What pretends this to dance, there's something in't,
I've revenged myself already upon my lord,
Yet deeper with my lady is the sweeter,
Something must be resolved. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Enough enough of conscience, let's reserve
Part of the mirth to another time, I shall
Meet some other hot worships at the ball;
Unless their apprehension prompt 'em,
Earlier to know their folly in pursuing me.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Madam, the gentlemen that were here this morning
In single visits are come all together,
And pray to speak with you.

div.stage: Enter Bostocke, Lamount, colonel, and Travers.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: Be confident she shall endure it.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: So so,
How d'ye gentlemen, you're very welcome.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter for that we do not come to be
Welcome, neither will we be welcome, speak Mr. Bostocke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But of our tongues, and in the names of these
Abused gentlemen, and myself I spit
Defiance, stand further off, and be attentive,
Weep or do worse, repentance wet thy linen,
And leave no vein for the doctor.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: There is no danger madam, let us hear 'em,
If they scold we two shall be hard enough for 'em,
And they were twenty.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Whose eyes shalt fire, and poison,
Malicious as a witch, and much more cunning,
Thou that dost ride men.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Worse than the night mare, let thy tongue be silent.
And take our scourges patiently, thou hast
In thy own self all the ingredients
Of wickedness in thy sex, able to furnish
Hell if it were insufficiently provided
With falsehood, and she fiend of thy own making
Circe that charmed men into swine, was not
So much a Jew as thou art, thou hast made
Us asses, dost thou hear?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But it is better we be all made such,
Than any one of us be monstered worse
To be an ox thy husband.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Spirit of flesh and blood I'll conjure thee,
And let the devil lay thee on thy back
I care not.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: That spirit of flesh and blood was well enforced.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You thought us animales insensible
Of all your jugglings did you Proserpine?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And that we loved, loved with a pox your phisnomy,
Know we but tried thee beldame, and thou art
Thyself a son oth' earth.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Twas a mistake, but she knows my meaning,
I begin to be a weary gentlemen,
I'll breathe a while.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: 'Tis time, and that you may
Not want encouragement take that.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: You shall know presently, dare but lift thy voice
To fright this lady, or but ask thy pardon,
My sword shall rip thy body for thy part,
And nail it on her threshold, or if you,
The proudest offer but in looks to justify
The baseness of this wretch your souls shall answer't.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: O impudence unheard, pardon madam
My tedious silence, the affront grew up
So fast I durst not trust my understanding
That any gentleman could attempt so much
Dishonour to a lady of your goodness;
Was this your project to make me appear
Guilty of that I hate beyond all sacrilege,
Was it for this you prayed my company,
You todpoles? 'tis your presence charms my sword,
Or they shall quickly pay their forfeit lives,
No altar could protect 'em.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Was it not his plot to have us rail?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: Say, shall I yet be active?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By no means,
This is no place for blood, nor shall any cause
Engage to such a danger.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Live to be
Your own vexations then till you be mad,
And then remove yourself with your own garters.
You sha'not go before I know from whose
Brain this proceeded, you are the mirth,
Was ever civil lady so abused
In her own house by ingrateful horseleeches?
Could your corrupted natures find no way
But this to recompense her noble favours,
Her courteous entertainments, would any
Heathens done like to you? admit she was
So just to say she could see nothing in you
Worthy her dearer thoughts as to say truth,
how could a creature of her wit and judgement
Not see how poor and miserable things
You are at best? must you impudent
In such a loud, and peremptory manner,
Disturb the quiet of her thoughts and dwelling
Gentlemen rather hinds scarce fit to mix,
Unless you mend her manners with her drudges.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This shows a nobleness, dost not Scutilla?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Why sir, did not you tell us?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: Be gone, lest I forget myself.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I have a token to remember you
A palsy upon your fingers noble colonel.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Was this his stratagem? we must be gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir I must thank ye, and desire your pardon,
For what has passed to your particular.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: You've more than satisfied my service in
Th'acknowledgement: disdain cannot provoke
Me to be so insolent.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: I can forget your last neglect, if you
Think me not too unworthy to expect
Some favour from you.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Why as
As a servant should that is ambitious?
To call you mistress, till the happier title
Of wife crown his desires.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I must confess,
This has won much upon me: but two words
To such a bargain, you're a gentleman,
I'm confident would adventure for me.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: As far as a poor life could speak my service.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That's fair and far enough, I make not any
Exception to your person.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Body enough
I hope to please a lady

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To that the least, I have estate for both.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Though if hold no comparison with your,
It keeps me like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: You honour me in this,
There's hope, if I can take a way that care,
You may be mine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir can you put me in security
That you have been honest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Been honest of your body, you are gentlemen,
Out of the wars live lazy, and feed high,
Drink the rich grape, and in canary may
Do strange things, when the wine has washed away
Discretion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do not urge you for the time to come.
Pray understand, have you been honest hitherto
And yet because you sha'not trouble friends
To be compurgators, I'll be satisfied;
If you will take your own oath that you are.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes sir, it will become me to be careful
Of my health, I'll take your own assurance,
If you can clear your body by an oath,
I'll marry none but you, before this gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: Your reason why you use me thus?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I wonder you will ask, do not I hear
How desperate some ha' been, what pain, what physic.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: This is a tale of a tub lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You rid no match without a shirt, to show ▪
The complexion of your body, I ha' done sir
When you resolve to swear you're honest, I
Vow to he yours, your wife: I am not hasty,
Think on't, and tell me when we meet again
Anon, tonight , tomorrow, when you please;
so farewell noble colonel, come Scutilla. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Is't come to this? I am jeered again, is't possible
To be honest at these years, a man of my
Complexion, and acquaintance? was ever
A gentleman put to this oath before a this fashion?
If I ha' the grace now to forswear myself,
Something may be done, and yet 'tis doubtful
She'll have more tricks, if widows be thus coltish,
The devil will have a task that goes a-wooing . Exit.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Such an affront my lord, I was ashamed on't,
A mere conspiracy to betray our fames ▪
But had you seen how poorly they behaved
Themselves, such carven knights, a pair of drone-bees
Ith' midst o'my vexation, if I could
Forbear to laugh, I ha' no blood in me,
They were so far from striking that they stood
Like images, things without life and motion,
Fear could not make so much as their tongue tremble,
Left all to me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: So so, what then did you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The lady laughed too, and the colonel
Increased his noise, to see how she derided
The poor knights.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Leave their character and proceed
To what you did.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You shall pardon me my lord,
I am not willing to report myself,
They and the lady, and the colonel
Can witness I came on.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But how came you off cousin? that must commend you.

sp.speaker: Bo,
sp.l: I ha my limbs my lord, no sign of loss
Of blood you see, but this was fortune, how
the colonel came off 'tis uncertain.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No, I left him, I think 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Upon my faith my lord I meant it not,
But wounds fall out some time when the swords in,
These are poor things to brag on, I ha' saved my
Self you see.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If it be so I'll call you cousin still, my satinist
Hark you shall beat this fellow.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Shall I my lord without cause?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He shall give you cause presently, how now
Gummed taffeta.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I pay for what I wear
My satin lord? your wardrobe does not keep
Me warm, I do not run oth' ticket with
The mercer's wife, and lecher out my debts
At country houses.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: There's something else you do not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I do not use to flatter such as you are,
Whose bodies are so rotten, they'll scarce keep
Their souls from breaking out, I write no odes
Upon your mistress to commend her postures,
And tumbling in a coach towards Paddington,
Whether you hurry her to see the pheasants,
And try what operation the eggs have
At your return, I am not taken with
Your mighty nonsense, gleaned from heathenish plays,
Which leave a curse upon the author for 'em,
Though I have studied to redeem you from
The infection of such books, which martyr sense
Worse than an almanac.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Excellent satire,
But lash not on, stop here, or I shall kick
Your learned worship.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: But do not, I advise you do not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: It will fall heavy o'some body, if your lordship
Kick me, I shall not spare your cousin there.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: On that condition what do you think o'that?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Excellently well followed by my troth la,
He'll pitch the bar well, I warrant, he does
So follow his kick.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Good, right as my leg again.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Your leg, 'twas he that kicked you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: D'ye think I do not feel it?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Why d'ye not use your toes then?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What for a merry touch,
A trick, a turn upon the toe, d'ye hear sir
You're good company, but if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Love you? why d'ye hear sir,
Ay, ay,
What a pox should any man see in you,
Once to think on you? love a squirt?
Shall I tell thee what thou art good for?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Good again, my lord observe him, for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yes thou wot stop a breach in a mud wall,
Or serve for a Priapus in the garden to
Fright away crows, and keep the corn, bean shatter,
Thou wot.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Or thou wot serve at Shrove tide to ha' thy legs
Broken with penny truncheons in the street,
'Tis pity any cock should stand the pelting,
And such a capon unpreferred.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Cry mercy you're a kinsman to the lord,
A gentleman of high and mighty blood.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But cold enough, wonot all this provoke him?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Dost hear? for all this I will undertake
To thrash a better man out of a wench.
That travels with her butter milk to market
Between two dorsers, any day oth' week,
My twice sod tail of green fish, I will do't
Or lose, my inheritance, tell me, and do not stammer,
When wert thou cudgeled last? what woman beat thee?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Thou art the town top,
A boy will set thee up, and make thee spin
Home with an eel-skin, do not marry, do not,
Thy wife will coddle thee, and serve thee up
In plates with sugar and rose water to
Him that had the grace to cuckold thee;
And if Pythagoras' transmigration
Of souls were true, thy spirit should be tenant
To a horse.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: A switch and spur would do some good upon you,
Why dost thou interfere, get the grincomes, go,
And straddle like a gentleman that would
Not shame his kindred, but what do I
Lose time with such a puppy?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways I'll justify thy wit
At my own peril.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I would speak with you,
Be not too busy with your lordship's legs,
I'll tell you somewhat.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I bestowed
A visit on the ladies which you wot on,
They have their wits still, and resolve to keep 'em,
They wonot hang themselves for a young lord,
Nor grow into consumption, other men
Have eyes, and nose, and lips, and handsome legs too:
So fare you well lord, my I left your kick
With your cousin buy buy otter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Very well.
But hark you cousin Bostocke, you have a mind
And modest constitution, I expected
You would have lifted up your leg.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To kick him,
Why, and you would ha' given a thousand pound,
I could not do't for laughing, beside,
He was your friend my lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Did you spare him
For that consideration?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Howsoever,
What honour had it been for me to quarrel?
Or wit indeed, if every man should take
All the abuses that are meant, great men
Would be laughed at, some fools must ha' their jests,
Had he been any man of blood or valour,
One that professed the sword, such as the colonel,
Less provocation would ha' made me active.

div.stage: Enter sr. Ambrose, and sr. Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The eagles takes no flies, is that it, how now
Sir Ambrose, and my honoured friend sr. Marmaduke?
You are strangers.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Now shall I be put to't, this taking will undo me?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Prithee tell me? is the colonel alive still?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Alive my lord, yes yes, he's alive.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Did your lordship think absolutely he was dead?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No my lord,
He is very well, but 'twas your kinsman's fortune.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: To have a blow, a box oth' ear.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: With his fist, and an indifferent round one.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Yes, yes he did strike me, I could ha' told you that,
But wherefore did he strike, ask 'em that.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If you would know my lord, he was our orator
To rail upon the lady for abusing us,
Which I confess he did with lung and spirit,
Which in the conclusion, the colonel
Stroke him toth' ground.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Take it: he gave it me my lord, I asked not for it.
But 'tis not yet revenged.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A little, but the place protected him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now since you had the greatest burden in
The affront.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Right, woe would know whether your resolution
Be first, to question him, for our cause appears
Subordinate, and may take breath till you
Ha called him to account.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I proclaim nothing,
And make no doubt the colonel will give me
Satisfaction like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: We are answered, and take our leave my lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: We shall meet at the ball anon gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Your lordship's servants: now to our design. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: My lord I take my leave too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Not yet cousin, you and I ha' not done.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You have cozened me too much.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thou most unheard of coward,
How dare you boast relation to me?
Be so impudent as to name, or think upon me,
Thou stain to honour, honour? thou'rt beneath
All the degrees of baseness: quit thy father,
Thy supposed one, and with sufficient testimony,
Some servingman leapt thy mother, or some juggler
That conjures with old bones, some woman's tailor,
When he brought home her petticoat, and took measure
Of her lose body, or I'll cullis thee
With a bottom.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Be so baffoul'd?
In presence of your mistress, 'tis enough
To make the blood of all thou knowest suspected,
And I'll ha' satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: For using of my name in ordinaries,
Ith' list of other whom you make your privilege,
To domineer, and win applause sometimes
With tapsters, and threadbare tobacco merchants,
That worship your gold lace, and ignorance
Stand bare, and bend their hams, when you belch out
My lord, and tother cousin in a bawdy-house,
Whom with a noise you curse by Jack and Tom,
For failing you at Fish-street, or the still-yard.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Not against your honour, but you shall see.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And vex my eyes to look on such a land-rat,
Were all these shames forgotten, how shall I
Be safe in honour with that noble lady,
To whom I sin fully commended thee,
Though 'twere not much, enough to make her think
I am as base as thou art, and the colonel,
And all that have but heard thee call me cousin,
What cure for this you malt-worm? o my soul
How it does blush to know thee, bragging puppy,
D'ye hear me thunder, and lightning, what
Nobility my predecessors boasted,
Or any man from honour's stock descended;
How many marquesses and Earls are numbered
In their great family? what coats they quarter,
How many battles our forefathers fought?
'Tis poor, and not becoming perfect gentry
To build their glories at their father's cost,
But at their own expense of blood or virtue,
To raise them living monuments, our birth
Is not our own act, honour upon trust,
Our ill deeds forfeit, and the wealthy sums
Purchased by others fame or sweat, will be
our stain, for we inherit nothing truly
But what our actions make us worthy of;
And are you not a precious gentleman,
Thou art not worth my steel, redeem this love
Some generous way of undertaking, or
Thou shalt be given up to boys, and ballets,
The scorn of footman, a disgrace more black
Than bastard, go to the colonel.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But now I think on't 'twill be necessary,
That first you right my honour with the lady,
You shall carry a letter, you will do't?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Such another conjuring will make me
Believe I am illegitimate indeed,
This came first keeping company with the blades,
From whom I learned to roar and run away:
I know 'tis a base thing to be a coward,
But every man is not born to be a Hercules,
Some must be beaten that others may be valiant. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Rosomond, and Honoria whispering, sr. Marmaduke, and sr. Ambrose following.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Let it be so, they will else be troublesome.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This cannot I hope displease you lady, 'tis
No new affection I protest, although
This be the first occasion I took
To express it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You did ill in the impression,
Although your bashfulness would not permit you
To speak in your own cause, you might have sent
Your meaning, I can make a shift to read
A scurvy hand, but I shall tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Is't possible your heart hath been tormented
In love's flame, and I the cause.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Your beauty hath the power
To melt a Cithians bosom, those divine
beams would make soft the earth, when rugged winter
Hath sealed the crannies up with frost, your eye
Will make the frigid region temperate,
Should you but smile upon't: account it then
No wonder if it turn my breast to ashes.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I see you are in love by your mention,
And cause I pity a gentleman should lose
His passion I'll acquaint you with a secret.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What misfortune 'twas
You did not first apply yourself to her
That can reward your love, and hath a heart
Spacious to entertain you; she does love you
Upon my knowledge strangely, and so
Commends you in your absence.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Say you so lady?
Pardon I beseech you the affection
I professed to your ladyship, 'twas but
A compliment, I am sorry I protest.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O 'tis excused sir, but I must tell you,
Perhaps you wonot find her now so tractable
Upon the apprehension she was slighted;
But to prescribe you confidence were to
Suspect your art, and bold discretion.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: 'Tis as I tell you sir, no lady in
The world can speak more praises of your body?
She knows not yet your mind.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And yet because she saw your compliments
Directed so unhappily to me,
I know not how you'll find her on the sudden,
But 'tis not half an hour since you possessed
The first place in her thoughts.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Shall I presume,
You will excuse the love I did present
Your ladyship? it was not from my heart,
I hope you will conceive so.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: 'Tis sufficient
That you recant no more neglect.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Be you so too; I'll justify thou shalt
Have cause.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: To wonder at you, what's your meaning sir?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sweet lady,
What thoughts make sad your brow? I have observed
Your eyes shoot clearer light.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You are deceived,
I am not melancholy.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Be for ever banished
The imagination of what can happen
To cloud so rare a beauty, you're in love.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: In love, who told you so?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: But that's no wonder,
We all may love, but you have only power
To conquer where you place affection, and triumph o'er your wishes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I love you, you're strangely sir mistaken,
Put your devices on some other lady,
I ha' been so far from my affection to you,
That I ha' laboured I confess to unsettle
The opinion of my lady Rosamond,
Who I confess loves you, and that extremely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How? she love me? than I ha' made fine work.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What cunning she is mistress of to hide
Her strange affections, or what power she has,
She does fly into your arms I know not.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Are you so dull?
Why, this was but to try your constancy,
I have heard her swear you are the properest knight,
The very Adonis: why, she has got your picture
And made it the only saint within her closet,
I blush at your credulity.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Is't e'en so?
I have undone myself with her already,
Pardon me gentle madam, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We are relieved,Enter monsieur.
Monsieur le Friske.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Tres humbla serviteur madam,
Me sweat with de haste to wait upon your ladyships;
I pray give me do leave dispatch presently,
For I must figaries to be done.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Gentlemen let your passions breathe a while,
A little music may correct the error,
And you may find yourselves.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: With all my heart sr. Marmaduke let's help
To exercise the ladies.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: And begar noting in de world mor profet
Your body den de motion all a more de France.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Ha de frisk you jump upon my name, and
Begar you have my nature to de right, heigh, and
All de world is but frisk.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Ha, monsieur madam aller,They dance.
Forboon, tres excellent begar, so I crave your patience
Madam, gentlemen, you be at de ball, mofoy you
See dat was never in dis world.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: What do you think dat is, me tell you, begar
You see me play de part of de Cupid.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Begar French Cupid, why? dear is no love like
De French love, dat is Cupid, love is hot, and de
French is hot

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: How comes it to pass that you are to play Cupid moun.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: My lord give me command me have device, and de mask
For de ladies, and me no trust little jacknape to play
Young Cupid but myself.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Cupid is a child, you have a beard monsieur.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Me care not de hair for dat, begar de little god may have
de little beard, Venus his mother have de mole, and Cupid
Her shield may have the black mussel.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But monsieur, we read Cupid was fair, and
You are black, how will that agree?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Cupid is fair, and monsieur is black, why monsieur
Is black den, and Cupid is fair, what is dat? A fair
Lady love de servant of the black
Complexion de ban eur, the colour is not de much,
Vulcan was de black smith, and Cupid may be de
Black gentleman his son legitimate.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: 'Tis de way to make Cupid the boy no bastard.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: But do you no publish this invention, me meet you
At de ball armed with quiver, and de bow.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: You wonot shoot us, I hope you'll spare our hearts.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Begar me shit you if me can, and your arts shall
Bleed one, two, tree, gallows adieu madam
Serviteur gentlemen tresemble.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Adieu monsieur, now madam with your favour,
I must renew my suit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You'd better buy a new one,
Nay then we shall be troubled. Exit.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You'll withdraw,
I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Come, come I know you love me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You may enlarge your folly my dear knight,
But I have pardoned you for love already.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This sha'not serve your turn, I came hither
Not to be jeered, and one of you shall love me. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Bostocke, lady Lucina and Scutilla.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Most gracious madam, my cousin your lord Loveall
Commends himself in black and white.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: You might ha' doubt in black and blue.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Scutilla how does thy poor soul, thou
Hast no husband nor children to commend me to.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: The poor soul's well, I hope your body is
recovered, dos not your left cheek burn still,
We ha' so talked on you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am sorry any gentleman that has relation to me should
Be so forgetful of your honour, and his own, but though he have
Forfeited opinion, let me continue innocent in your thoughts?
I have sent you a small jewel to expiate my offence for
Commending him, I expect your ladyship at the ball,
Where you shall make many happy to kiss your hand,
And in their number the true admirer of your virtue,
My lord is honourable.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nay faith my lord is right, I ha' not met
The colonel since you know when.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: You ha' more reason to remember.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I would be so bold to ask you a question.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In the mean time give me leave, we are none
But friends, I know you're valiant.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No, no, you do not know't, but I know myself.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But will you answer me? why did not you strike him again?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But blood are not a like, terms were not even,
If I had killed him there had been an end.

sp.speaker: Bo.
