sp.l: Right madam, but if he had wounded me,
He might ha' killed, heaven knows how many.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: D'ye not conceive it? so many drops of mine,
So many gentlemen, nay more, who knows
Which of these might ha' been a knight, a lord.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Princes came from the blood,
And should I hazard such a severation
Against a single life, 'tis not I fear
To fight with him by these hills, but what wise gamester
Will venture a hundred pound to a flawed six pence?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And he were ten coronels, I'll not endure his company ▪
Sweet lady, you and I'll retire.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: He should not seek me then.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: He should rather hardly find you, I'm your servant. Exi.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I was wishing for you sir,
Your judgement of these diamonds.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: They were a lord's, sent me for a token,
You cannot choose but know him, the lord Loveall.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: So, so, so, I am like to speed.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is not he a pretty gentleman?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: And you are sure he's honest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As lords go now adays that are
In fashion;
But cry you mercy, you ha' put me in mind,
I did propound a business to you sir.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: And I came prepared to answer you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, I'll call one to be a witness.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: That was not I remember in our covenant,
You sha'not need.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll fetch you a book to sware by ▪

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Let it be Venus and Adonis then,
Or Ovid's wanton elegies, Aristotle's
Problems, Guy of Warwick, or sr. Beavis,
Or if there be a play book you love better,
I'll take my oath upon your epilogue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You're very merry, well, swear how you please.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: In good time,
You do expect now I should swear I'm honest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes sir, and 'tis no hard condition,
If you reflect upon my promise.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To marry you, which act must make you lord
Of me and my estate, a round possession,
Some men have gone to hell for a less matter.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: But I wonot be damned for twenty thousand
such as you are, and every one a million,
And I the authority of a parliament
To marry wi'ye all, I would not buy
This flesh now I ha' sworn.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I think so colonel,
Bless me? twenty thousand wives, 'twould ne'er
Come to my turn, and you'd not live to give
The tithe benevolence.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: They would find pages, fools, or gentlemen-vshers.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then upon the matter,
You being not willing sir to take your oath,
I may be confident you are not honest.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Why look upon me lady, and consider
With some discretion what part about me
Does look so tame you should suspect me honest,
How old d'ye think I am?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Some ith' world doubted me not so much,
At thirteen I was ever plump and forward,
My dry nurse swore at seven, I kissed like one
Of five and twenty, setting that aside ,
What's my profession?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: So examine a whole army, and find one
Soldier that hates a handsome woman, we cannot march
Without our bag and baggages, and is it possible,
When we come home where women's pride, and all
Temptation to wantonness abounds
We should lose our activity?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: When we have our pay,
We vow no chastity till we marry, lady
'Tis out of fashion indeed with gentlemen
To be honest, and of age together 'tis sufficient,
We can provide to take our pleasures too,
Without infection, a sound body is
A treasure I can tell you, yet if that
Would satisfy you, I should make no scruple
To swear, but otherwise you must pardon us
As we must pardon you.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Yes you, as if you ladies had not your vagaries,
and martial discipline, as well as we,
Your outworks, and redoubts, your court of guard,
Your sentries, and perdues, sallies, retreats,
Pasties, and stratagems, women are all honest,
Yes, yes, exceeding honest; let me ask you
One question, I'll not put you to your oath,
I do allow you Hyde-park, and spring-garden,
You have a recreation called the ball,
A device transported hither by some ladies
That affect tennis, what d'ye play a set?
There's a foul racket kept under the line,
Strange words are bandied, and strange revels madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But if men had no more wit, and honesty,
They would let fall their stings on something else,
This is discoursed, but when corantoes fail,
Or news at ordinaries, when the phlegmatic Dutch
Ha ta'en no fisher-boats, or our cole-ships land
Safe at Newcastle, you're fine gentlemen,
But to conclude of that we met for your honesty,
Not justified by an oath, as I expected,
Is now suspended, will you swear yet.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Why, I thought you had been a christian? widow
Have I not told you enough, you may meet one
Will forfeit his conscience, and please you better,
Some silkworm oth' city, or the court,
There be enough will swear away their soul
For your estate, but I have no such purpose,
The wars will last I hope.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So so, Scutilla. Enter Scutilla.
You were present when I promised the colonel,
To be his wife upon condition.
He could secure my opinion by his oath,
That he was honest, I am bound in honour
Not to go back, you've done it, I am yours sir,
Be you a witness to this solemn contract.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: Are you in earnest lady, I ha' not sworn.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You have given better truth,
He that can make this conscience of an oath
Assures his honesty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's past
I question not, if for the time to come
Your love be virtuous to me.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Most religious,
Or let me live the soldier's dishonour,
And die the scorn of gentlemen, I ha' not
Space enough in my heart to entertain thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is not this better than swearing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now I may call you husband?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: No title can more honour me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If please you I'll show you then my children.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ha' six that call me mother.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The elder may want softness to acknowledge you,
But some are young enough, and may be counselled
To ask your blessing, does this trouble you?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Trouble me? no, but it is the first news lady
Of any children.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, they are not like
To be a burden to us, they must trust
To their own portions left 'em by their father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But of my estate, I cannot keep ▪
Any thing from 'em, and I know you are
So honest, you'd not wish me wrong the orphans,
'Tis but six thousand pound in money colonel
Among them all, beside some trifling plate
And jewels worth a thousand more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My jointure will be firm to us, two hundred
Per annum.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Is it so? and that will keep
A country house, some half a dozen cows,
We shall ha' cheese and buttermilk, one horse
Will serve me, and your man to ride to markets.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Canst be content to live ith' country colonel?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: And watch the pease, look to the hay, and talk ▪
Of oats and stubble, I ha' been brought up to't,
And for a need can thrash.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Ith' year, beside my skill in farrowing pigs,
O 'tis a wholesome thing to hold the plough,
And wade up to the calf ith' dirty furrows ▪
worse than sleeping in a trench, or quagmire,
You ha' not heard me whistle yet.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Why? there's it, she does counterfeit, well lady,
Be you in jest or earnest, this is my
Resolution I'll marry you, and y'ad forty children,
And not a foot of land to your jointure, heaven
Will provide for, and we do our endeavours,
Where be the children, come how many boys.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: As many as can get sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No more.
Since you're so noble, know I tried your patience,
And now I am confirmed, my estate is yours
Without the weight of children or of debts,
Love me, and I repent not.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Sayest thou so?
I would we had a priest here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There remains to take away one scruple.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have none, 'tis your doubt sir,
And ere we marry you shall be convinced
Some malice has corrupted your opinion
Of that we call the ball.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will entreat your company tonight ,
Where your own eyes shall lead you to accuse
Or vindicate our fames.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Madam, Mr. Bostocke
Expects within.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You shall be reconciled to him.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: With Bostocke willingly, than tooth ball,
Which for your sake I dare not now suspect,
Where union of hearts such empire brings,
Subjects methings are crowned as we as Kings. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus ▪ quintus.
div.stage: Enter monsieur and servants with perfume.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Bone for bone here a little, dear a little more, my
Lord hire dis house of the city merchant, begar
It smell musty, and he will have all sweet for de
ladies, perfume, perfume every corner presently
For dear is purpose to make all smoke anon
Begar;Enter lady Rosomond and Honoria.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: He wait on you presently monsieur de freshwater.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Monsieur le Friske these ladies were pleased
To command my attendance hither.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Welcome to de ball, par ma foy
You pardon monsieur, I have much trouble
In my little head, I can no stay to
Compliment, a vostre service. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: In all my travels, I have not seen a more
Convenient structure.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Now you talk of your travels signior, till my lord
Come you shall do us a special favour to
Discourse what passages you ha' seen abroad.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Were you ever abroad before signior.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I hardly ever was at home, and yet
All countries lost wiseman are his own?
Did you never travel ladies,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: We are no ladies errant, 'tis enough
For such as you, that look for state employment.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Yet there be ladies ha' your languages,
And married to great men prove the better statesmen.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: We have heard talk of many countries.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: And you may hear talk, but give me the man
That has measured 'em, talks but talk.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Have you seen a fairer city than London?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: To what it will be a hundred years hence.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I have heard much talk of Paris.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: You have been there I me sure. Enter lord.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I tell you madam, I took shipping at
Gravesend, and had no sooner passed
The cantons, and Grissons, making some stay
In the Valtoline, but I came to Paris a pretty
Hamlet, and much in the situation like Dunstable,
'Tis in the province of Alcontora, some three leagues
distant from civil, from whence we have our oranges.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I have heard civil is in Spain.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You may hear many things,
The people are civil that live in Spain, or there
May be one town like another, but if civil
Be not in France, I was never at civil in my life.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Do not I know Paris, it was built by the youngest son
Of King Priam, and was called by his name, yet some
Call it Lutetia, because the gentlewomen there
Play so well upon the lute.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Here I observed many remarkable buildings, as the
University, which some call the Loure, where the
Students made very much of me, and carried me
To the bear-garden, where I saw a play on the
Bankside, a very pretty comedy called Martheme,
In London.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But there be no such comedians as we have here,
Yet the women are the best actors, they play
Their own parts, a thing much desired in England
By some ladies, inns a court gentlemen, and others,
But that by the way.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I had stayed longer there, but I was offended with a
Villainous scent of onions, which the wind brought from
St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Onions would make you sleep well.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But the scent 'tis not to be endured, I smelled
On 'em when I came to Rome, and hardly scaped the
Inquisition fort.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Were you at Rome too signior.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: 'Tis in my way to Venice, I'll tell you madam I was very
Loath to leave their country.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Right, for I had a very good inn, where mine host
Was a notable good fellow, and a Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: O the catches we sang, and his wife a pretty woman,
And one that warms a bed one oth' best in Europe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Did you ever hear the like.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Right, had a shrewd pate, and his ears were something
O'th longest, for one upon the oath of a w —
Walloon that — from Spain to the low -
Countries, and the other from Lapland into Germany.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A perilous head, and yet loving to his guests,
As mine host banks, as red in the gills, and as merry
A — but anger him, and he sets all Christendom
Together by the ears, well shortly after I left
France, and sailing along the Alps, I came to
Lombardy, where I left my cloak, for it was very
Hot travelling, and went a pilgrim to Rome
Where I saw the tombs, and a play in Pompey's
Theater, here I was kindly entertained by an anchorite,
In whose chamber I lay, and drink cider.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: What should I trouble you with many storeys? from hence
I went to Naples, a soft kind of people, and clothed
In silk, from thence I went to Florence from whence we
Have the art of working custards, which we call
Florentines, Milan a rich state of
Haberdashers, permount, where I had excellent venison,
And Padua, famous for the pads, or easy saddles
Which our physicians ride upon, and first brought from
Thence when they commenced doctor.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I see little in Mantua, beside dancing upon the ropes,
Only their strong beer, better than any I
Ever drunk at the trumpet, but Venice of all
The champion countries, do not mistake they are the
Valiantest gentlemen under the sun.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: O the catazaners we turned there.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Two or three magnifico's grandees of the state,
We tickled 'em in the very pialto, by the same
Token two or three English spies told us they had lain
Leger three months to steal away the piatzo, and ship
It for covent. Garden, a pretty fabric and building
Upon the — but I was compelled to make
Short stay here by reason of the Duke's concubines
Fell in love we me, gave me a ring of his, out of
A solid diamond, which afterwards I lost washing my
Hands in the salt water.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You should ha' fished fort, and as good luck as
She that found her wedding ring in the
Haddock's belly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No, there was no staying, I took post-horse presently
For Genoa, and from thence to Madrill, and so to
The Netherlands.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: And how sped you among the Dutch?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why, we were drunk every day together, they get their
Living by it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And making bargains in their tippling,
The Jews are innocent, nay the devil himself
Is but a dunce to 'em, of whose trade they are.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: They fish, they fish still, who can help it, they
Have nets enough, and may catch the province
In time then let the kingdoms look about 'em,
They can't be idle, and they have one advantage
Of all the world, they'll ha' no conscience to trouble
'Em, I heard in whispered they want butter, they have
A design to charm the Indies, and remove their
Dairy, but that as a secret, shall go no further;
I caught a surfeit of boar in holland, upon my
Recovery I went to Flushing, where I met with a handsome
Froe, with whom I went to Middleborough, by the —
And lest her drunk at Rotterdam, there I took
Shipping again for France, from thence to Dover,
from Dover to Gravesend, from Gravesend to Queen -
Hive, and from thence to what I am come to.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And noble signior you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I hope he did not overhear me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I am much honoured ladies in your presence.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Absence had been a sin my lord where you ▪
Were pleased to invite. Enter monsieur.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Fie, fie, my lord give me one ear.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Interrupt me no more good monsieur.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Monsieur la Friske, a word, a word, I beseech you,
No excuser moy. Exit Fresh. and Moun.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Have you thought ladies of your absent servant?
Within whose heart the civil war of love,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: May end in a soft peace.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: We had armies too my lord, of wounded thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And are you agreed to which I must devote
My loving service, and which is wisest, fairest,
Is it concluded yet?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You did propound
A hard province, and we could not
Determine as you expected, but if
Your flame be not extinct, we have devised
Another way.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: You make my ambition happy,
And indeed I was thinking 'twas impossible
That two such beauties should give place to either,
And I am still that humble notary
To both your loves.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Then this we have made lots,
That what we cannot, fate may soon divide,
And we are fixed to obey our destiny,
There is but two, one and your wishes guide you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And will you satisfy my chance.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We should
Be else unjust.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Your hat my lord,
If you vouchsafe the favour?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Dare you expose your head to the air so long?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: That draw which quickly tell how much I love you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So, so now let me see, I commend your device,
Since I am uncapable of both,
This is a way indeed, but your favour.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Let's have fair play my lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: What fool is he?
That having the choice of mistresses will be
Confined to one, and rob himself, I am yet
The favourite of both these, is no policy,
I could make shift with both a-bed.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: In troth, and so I am, and in the mind
I am in, will give myself no cause toth' contrary,
D'ye see? I'll draw you both.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How? both.
You cannot otherwise be reconciled,
I'll be content to marry one, and do
Service to th' others petticoat, I must tell you,
I am not without precedent.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Within the name of Venus, — ha a blank ▪
By this light nothing, neither name nor mark.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: 'Tis quickly solved,
Your lordship was too confident,
We never were at such a loss my lord,
As with the hazard of our wit or honour
To court you with so desperate affection.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: By our example know, some ladies may
Commend, nay love a gentleman, and yet
Be safe in their own thoughts, and see as far
As modesty, and honour will allow us,
We are still servants to your lordship,

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Say so? why look you ladies that you may perceive,
How I can be temperate too; first, I thank you
Heartily, and to recompense your wit ▪
Present another lottery, you sha'not
Suspect I have a thought that will betray
Your innocence to scandal, let me entreat
you take your chance too, this for you madam,
And this is left your fortune, do me honour
To wear these pair of jewels for my sake,
So with a confidence of your happy pardon,
To what is passed hereafter I shall pay
To your true virtues, better service than
So unnecessary trials.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And to show
We are not coy my lord, we'll wear your jewel.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And be their ornament.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: All happiness to your lordship,
Your cruells are not full set noble ladies.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Your presence will so ne make us active, madam
I was bold.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: She has your diamond my lord.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nay, nay, we are friends, are
We not madam?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: The colonel too has given me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: As much as I desired, and here's my hand,
While I can draw a sword command me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To put it up again, all friends, all friends,
A pox a quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Kiss my hand, kiss my — noble ladies here.

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.l: Why is music silent all this while?
Has it no voice to bid these ladies welcome?

div.stage: A golden ball descends, enter Venus and Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Come boy now draw thy powerful bow,
Here are ladies' hearts enough
To be transfixed, this meeting is
To ruffle ladies, and to kiss,
These are my orgies, from each eye ▪
A thousand wanton glances fly;
Lords, and ladies of the game,
Each breast be full of my own flame:
Why shoots not Cupid? these are all,
met in honour of my ball,
Which Paris gave to Ida hill,
I'll maintain these revels still:
Why stays Cupid all this while.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: These are none of Venus' train,
No spark of this lascivious fire,
Dwells in their bosoms, no desire,
But what doth fill Diana's breast,
In their modest thoughts do rest.
Venus this new festival,
Shall be still Diana's ball:
A chaste meeting ever here,
Seek thy votaries other where.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You're chaste indeed, do not we know,
You to your sweetheart nightly go,
Envying one is not kissed, no you
On his face but let fall due ▪
Some may wonder what doth ail,
Your lips but kisses made them pale
Methinks the moon should blush,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I do
Some times, but 'tis for such as you:
Then hide myself within a mist,
For shame to see thee clipped and kissed.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Draw Cupid, shall thy mother be
Brand by a huntress, let me see
I want one shaft.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Mother not so,
You may quickly break my bow,
Here Diana doth command,
My bow is frozen to my hand,
Beside, the lady's breasts are here,
Such proofs against my shafts I fear,
Each arrow would to our disgrace,
Break, or rebound in my own face;
Mother, fly hence or you will be,
if you'll stay, made as chaste as she.

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Can her magic charm them so,
Then 'tis time that Venus go
To seek her own more choice delight,
Against my will, enjoy this night.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Cupid if you mean to stay,
Throw your licentious shafts away,
Than you are love, then be embraced,
Love is welcome while he's chaste;
Now some other strain to show,
What pleasures to this night we owe. A dance.

div.stage: Enter Barker, like a satire dancing.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: My lord, my ladies, will you see a monster,
I have not met such another in all my travails.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What have we here a satire.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wonder that a satire can
Put off wildness and turn man,
Love, such miracles can do,
But this owes itself to you
Bright lady.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Keep the goblin from me gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: No more, the cynic, I protest
You have converted me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I am the man you did encourage madam
To learn to dance, I shall do better shortly,
Your love will perfect me, and make me soft,
And smooth as any reveller.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, my love, I am not mad to love a satire,
For that's thy best condition, judgement all,
How scurvily this civility shows in him.
Faith rail, and keep your humour, still it shows excellent,
Does he not become the beast,
The lords allow you pension.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You are a witch, I'll justify it, and there is not
one honest thought among the whole sex of you,
D'ye laugh, lose witted ladies, there are not
In hell such furies, that's a comfort yet
To him that shall go thither, he shall have
Less torment after death than he finds here.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Your wit has got the squirt too, I'll traduce
Your ball for this, and if there be a post,
That dares write mischief, look to be worse
Than executed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He will come to himself again, when he hath purged
Freshwater.

div.stage: Enter sir Stephen, and sir Lionell.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Madam your servants beg this favour from you.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: That since your resolutions will admit
No change of hearts you will not publish how
We ha' been jeered.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Not jeered, but you came on so desperate.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We love our own when we preserve,
Gentlemen's honour.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Mercy and silence as you are honourable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why if I must gentlemen, you imagine I ha' been
At Venice, but I stayed at Gravesend
All this summer expecting a wind, and finding it
So uncertain, will defer the voyage till the spring,
I am not the first whom the winds, and seas have crossed.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Then you have crossed no sea?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: If you please, I'll require
But my principal, and for your good company,
I'll stay at home for good, and all to be merry.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you shall go your voyage,
We would not have you lose the benefit
Of travel, when you come home, you may summon
Your debtors by a drum, and showing your bag
of certificates.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Receive your money when you can get it, and be
Knighted.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I thank you gentlemen, I am in a way now,
I have sold my land, and put out my money
To live I see my heart wonot dance tonight ,
I may to Gravesend in the morning,
I can be but pickled in salt water, and I'll
Venture one drowning to be revenged
Again, again, set, set.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What think you of all this?

sp.speaker: Colonel
sp.p: To my wishes, an innocent, and generous recreation.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ladies and gentlemen, now a banquet waits you,
Be pleased to accept, 'twill give you breath and then,
Renew our revels, and toth' ball again.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
